channel.title: BBC News - Technology

item.title: Royole's bendy-screen FlexPai phone unveiled in China
item.description: The FlexPai phone offers a tablet-sized screen when open or three separate displays when folded up.

item.title: Robot backpack: How this Fusion bot aids collaboration
item.description: The Fusion bot shares and teaches skills by transferring body motions from one person to another.

item.title: Fake Cambridge Analytica ad hits Facebook
item.description: The bogus advert purports to be for the BeLeave Brexit campaign and received more than 1,000 views.

item.title: US attacks UK plan for digital services tax on tech giants
item.description: Plans to impose a new tax on tech giants risk US retaliation and could hurt trade relations.

item.title: Apple Watch owners asked to return devices for repair after update glitch
item.description: Apple has withdrawn a software update after complaints that it "bricked" some owners' smartwatches.

item.title: Eurostar resets customer passwords after hack attack
item.description: The rail firm reset passwords after detecting efforts to break into some accounts earlier this month.

item.title: Robot company Starship Technologies start Milton Keynes deliveries
item.description: Hundreds of robots are starting to deliver packages to addresses across Milton Keynes.

item.title: Mobile phone shop staff 'enabling Sim swap scams'
item.description: Fraudsters are using lax ID checks at phone shops to commit identity theft, a BBC investigation finds.

item.title: Google executive leaves after sexual harassment claim
item.description: The New York Times reported the executive had been accused of sexual harassment in 2013.

item.title: Can artificial intelligence help stop religious violence?
item.description: Oxford University researchers have created a simulation designed to help prevent religious conflict.

item.title: Android's under-5s apps have 'unfair and deceptive' ads
item.description: Campaign groups and university researchers raise concerns about the ads found in Android apps.

item.title: Police ground drones after reports they fall out of the sky
item.description: Some incidents in which DJI drones "suffered a complete loss of power" have concerned UK authorities.

item.title: Yosemite fall: Victims identified as married bloggers from India
item.description: The couple who fell to their deaths had blogged about their love for travel and each other.

item.title: Cardiff tech firm: 'We'll pay £100k, but can't get staff'
item.description: A tech skills shortage means some Welsh workers receive daily job offers, and salaries are increasing.

item.title: Fifa: Governing body reveals IT data hack earlier this year
item.description: Football's world governing body Fifa says information was hacked from its IT systems earlier this year.

item.title: Facebook daily visits growth slows as sales miss forecasts
item.description: The social media firm is seeing users shift from its most profitable business amid rising costs.

item.title: Porn-loving US official spreads malware to government network
item.description: The employee at the US Geological Survey had an "extensive history" of visiting adult websites.

item.title: Pittsburgh shooting: Gab drops offline after attack
item.description: PayPal and others pulled support for Gab's "free speech" service after a gun attack on a synagogue.

item.title: Teaching kids the magic of coding
item.description: Linda Liukas wants to show children that writing code for computers can be magical.

item.title: Red Hydrogen One: The internet reacts to the 3D-enabled phone
item.description: A smartphone with a pioneering 3D display fails to convince technology experts of its merits.

item.title: Sony eyes record profit as gaming hits boost earnings
item.description: Strong demand for Spider-Man and other games is helping drive earnings at the Japanese electronics giant.

item.title: MIT invites you to control a human on Halloween
item.description: Researchers want internet users to vote on which actions an actor will take in a new social experiment.

item.title: Uber appeals against drivers' rights to pay and holiday
item.description: The taxi-hailing app appeals against a ruling its drivers should be treated as workers, not self employed.

item.title: Budget 2018: Tech giants face digital services tax
item.description: Chancellor Philip Hammond plans to tax the sales that digital giants generate in the UK.

item.title: Dad creates VR world to help daughter
item.description: Craig Chaytor's 360° videos were inspired by his daughter's learning difficulties.

item.title: Driverless cars: Who should die in a crash?
item.description: A global study suggests people prefer to save young over elderly people.

item.title: Facebook finds more fake accounts from Iran
item.description: The social network has removed another batch of pages and groups spreading misinformation.

item.title: Fatal 'swatting' hoaxer faces more charges
item.description: The long list of suspected crimes relate to many other hoax calls to police, fraud and threats of violence.

item.title: Google sacks dozens over sexual harassment
item.description: The tech giant says it dismissed 48 employees, including 13 senior managers, over the past two years.

item.title: Portrait by AI program sells for $432,000
item.description: The AI-generated portrait of a fictional Frenchman sold for 45 times its original estimate.

item.title: BA investigation into website hack reveals more victims
item.description: Details of the attack emerged as BA investigated a 'sophisticated' attack it suffered in September.

item.title: Facebook fined £500,000 for Cambridge Analytica scandal
item.description: The Cambridge Analytica scandal was a "serious breach" of data protection laws, UK regulator says.

item.title: Inside Rockstar: The developer behind Red Dead Redemption 2
item.description: The western-style adventure is the first major release from Rockstar Games for eight years.

item.title: How WhatsApp is being abused in Brazil's elections
item.description: Software is being used to scrape phone numbers and send thousands of messages in minutes.

item.title: Twitter earnings boosted by major sports broadcasts
item.description: Sales leap 30% in the third quarter, partly thanks to broadcasts of major US soccer and baseball games.

item.title: BT appoints Worldpay's Philip Jansen as new chief executive
item.description: Philip Jansen takes the helm next year as Britain's biggest telecoms provider seeks to revive its fortunes.

item.title: Cathay Pacific data hack hits 9.4 million passengers
item.description: The Hong Kong airline said personal details including passport and credit card numbers were accessed.

item.title: Tesla delivers 'historic' $311m profit
item.description: Elon Musk's electric car maker reports only the third quarterly profit in its 15-year history.

item.title: Hi-tech glasses offer alternative to bifocals
item.description: The regular prescription lenses can change to bifocals and back again at the touch of a button.

item.title: Mitsubishi windows shine 'alarmingly realistic' fake sunlight
item.description: Mitsubishi has developed a new indoor lighting system that mimics blue skies, sunrises and sunsets.

item.title: Portal: Facebook's new home gadget
item.description: Facebook's Portal offers video chat around the home - but do consumers trust Facebook enough?

item.title: The world’s first fully-autonomous indoor farm
item.description: The world’s first fully-autonomous indoor farm in San Carlos, California, is now operational.

item.title: 'Video games made me a better surgeon'
item.description: Rather than impede learning, gaming can improve your manual dexterity and concentration skills, one surgeon says.

item.title: Japan bullet train stops 'scary' safety drills
item.description: Workers at the Japanese company would crouch in trenches beside railway tracks as trains sped by.

item.title: Why robots will build the cities of the future
item.description: As construction workforces age, we are likely to turn to robots to build the cities of the future.

item.title: What should I do with my broken kettle?
item.description: Our household appliances could have much longer lives if they were designed to be easily repaired.

item.title: Can we predict when a crime will take place?
item.description: Predictive policing using data analytics is gaining acceptance among police forces, but at what cost?

item.title: Five things to know about Red Dead Redemption 2
item.description: The hotly anticipated video game is released this week.

item.title: The boss who tried to kill his business
item.description: Peter Reinhardt was initially unimpressed with the idea behind customer data tech firm Segment.

item.title: Helping kids cope with the fear of medical treatment
item.description: Hi-tech gadgets are helping sick children express their feelings and soothe their fears.

item.title: 'A cyber-attack could stop the country'
item.description: As the internet of things takes off, is security being sacrificed in the quest for higher speeds?

item.title: Asteroid pioneers: The team who put rovers on a space rock
item.description: Japan's space agency Hayabusa-2 spacecraft is the first one to place robot rovers on an asteroid's surface.

item.title: Robot seeks out skin cancer with suction
item.description: Fitted with a dermatoscope, the prototype can check for signs of skin abnormalities.

item.title: How to boost the alarm in your smartphone
item.description: Kate Russell on how to make sure you never sleep through your alarm again.

item.title: Yusaku Maezawa: Why I've bought a ticket to the Moon
item.description: Space X's mission to the Moon will be the first lunar journey by humans since 1972.

item.title: Bitcoin: The first ten years
item.description: Bitcoin was born ten years ago. What has it brought the world?

item.title: Are hydrogen trains the future of UK travel?
item.description: Trains that emit pure water could be in the UK by the "early 2020s", according to the government.

item.title: VR esports: Is it gaming for sporty people?
item.description: VR esport athlete Tim McGuinness says the technology lets him do things traditional sport competitors cannot.

item.title: The robot arm made for gentle undersea exploration
item.description: A soft robotic arm which will allow underwater sea life to be studied in greater detail is created.

item.title: Micro drones pull heavy objects and other tech news
item.description: BBC Click's Omar Mehtab looks at some of the best technology news stories of the week.

item.title: Camera lens made of ice takes cool photos
item.description: Photographer Mathieu Stern made a camera lens from a chunk of an iceberg.
